home.projectIntro: Berlin has over 220 public drinking fountains — but fewer than 40 are visible on Google Maps. Information about clean drinking water is scattered and often hard to find. Our project makes it easy for everyone to locate free, safe drinking water across the city.
home.subproject1Description: We created a simple Google Map with all known public drinking fountains in Berlin. Save it to your phone and quickly find water whenever you need it.
home.subproject2Description: We’re working to bring more drinking fountains to quieter neighborhoods outside Berlin’s busy center — areas that currently lack this essential infrastructure — so everyone has easy access to free water.

subprojects.subproject1FullDescription: Berlin has plenty of free drinking water points, but they're not always easy to find—especially on everyday platforms like Google Maps. To make things easier, we've created a custom Google Map that shows fountains from Berliner Wasserbetriebe, which are available 24/7, as well as government buildings where you can refill during regular business hours.
subprojects.subproject1Details: We have already added drinking fountains from Berliner Wasserbetriebe and aim to create a comprehensive overview of free water sources in Berlin.
subprojects.subproject2FullDescription: Another part of our initiative is promoting the installation of new drinking fountains in high-traffic areas in Pankow.
subprojects.subproject2Details:
We know that similar initiatives have already been successfully implemented in other districts of the city. We hope that by the end of our project, we will be able to prepare a guide that will help residents of other districts achieve the installation of drinking fountains in their areas.

As part of the project, we decided to focus on installing drinking fountains in two locations: at Kissingen-Stadion (Kissingenstraße sports ground, Forchheimer Str. 22, 13189 Berlin) and at the large children's playground on Trelleborger Straße. In both places, we see great need, as many children, teenagers, athletes, and families come there daily. A freely accessible drinking fountain would significantly improve the quality of life there.

about.title: About Us
about.intro: We, Nina and Maria, are currently working on a civil society project that aims to make information about free drinking water sources in Berlin more accessible. This is part of our participation in the Club Dialog e.V. program.
about.programDescription: We are participating in the ["Informieren. Nachdenken. Aktivierung"](https://www.club-dialog.de/ina/) project by Club Dialog e.V. The program supports Berlin residents with a migration background in strengthening their political and social participation. It covers topics ranging from democracy and civil society to practical skills for developing and implementing community infrastructure projects.

privacy.intro: This privacy policy explains how we collect, use, and protect your personal information when you visit our website, in compliance with the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and applicable German data protection laws.

Berlin Drinking Fountains Initiative
Email: berlinertrinkbrunnen@gmail.com
privacy.dataProcessedContent:
When you visit our website, we automatically collect certain information about your device, including information about your web browser, IP address, time zone, and some of the cookies that are installed on your device. Additionally, as you browse the site, we collect information about the individual web pages that you view, what websites or search terms referred you to the site, and information about how you interact with the site.

This data is processed on the legal basis of our legitimate interest (Art. 6(1)(f) GDPR) in improving our website and understanding user behavior to provide better services.

No other personal data such as names, email addresses, or contact details are collected or processed by us.

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.intro: Find answers to common questions about our initiative.
faq.projectFaqsTitle: Questions about our initiative and goals
faq.mapFaqsTitle: Questions about using our water map

questions.question: Why can’t I find most fountains on Google Maps?
questions.answer:
[The Berliner Wasserbetriebe (BWB)](https://www.bwb.de/de/trinkbrunnen.php), the company that installs the fountains, only lists them on their own website. They do not integrate the locations with Google Maps. Instead, they provide a downloadable .kml file with all fountain coordinates.

We’ve made it easier for you by turning that data into a Google Maps layer you can add directly to your phone. We also included other public water sources such as libraries, open public schools, and more.

For even more refill points, check out [Refill](https://refill-deutschland.de/) Berlin, which lists businesses and organizations participating in their program.

questions.question: How does water map work?
questions.answer: We’ve taken the BWB data and other sources and created a map you can add to your Google Maps app as an extra layer. This way, you can see all known public water points right in your regular map view.

questions.question: How do I add this map to my Google Maps app?
questions.answer: Visit our map page, tap the download button, and the new layer will be added to your Google Maps app. You can remove it anytime.

questions.question: Can I suggest a new location for the map?
questions.answer: Yes! Just write to us at the address listed in the footer.

questions.question: What areas are you focusing on first?
questions.answer: We are starting with underserved districts outside the busy city center, beginning in Pankow and Lichtenberg.

questions.question: Who decides where new drinking fountains are installed?
questions.answer: The Berlin Senate (Senatsverwaltung) decides that together with the Berliner Wasserbetriebe and local district authorities.

questions.question: Who funds the installation and maintenance of fountains?
questions.answer: The Berlin Senate funds both the installation and maintenance, and the Berliner Wasserbetriebe manages the work.

questions.question: How much does it cost to install and maintain a fountain?
questions.answer: Installing one fountain costs around €12,000–15,000. Maintenance, including water testing, costs about €3,700 per year.

questions.question: Are the fountains safe to drink from?
questions.answer: Yes. Water from each fountain is tested every 4 weeks to ensure it meets safety standards.

questions.question: Why do fountains run water constantly? Isn’t that wasteful?
questions.answer: The constant flow prevents water from standing in the pipes, which reduces the risk of bacterial growth. The drained water is used to water trees in some locations.

questions.question: When are the fountains operational during the year?
questions.answer: They operate from May to October each year to avoid freezing in winter.

questions.question: How can I help support your initiative?
questions.answer: If you know anyone in district authorities, the Berlin Senate (especially, the MVKU department), or other relevant offices, please connect us. You can also share our map and project with friends and local community groups.

questions.question: How can I hide or show water sources in Google Maps?
questions.answer:
If you don’t want to see water sources from the custom map in the Google Maps app, tap “You” at the bottom of the screen, scroll all the way down, and select “Maps.” Then tap the name of the map and choose “Close” to hide the water sources. This will temporarily remove the map from your view.

You can learn more on the [official Google support page](https://support.google.com/maps/answer/3045850?hl=en&co=GENIE.Platform%3DiOS).

questions.question: Where did you get the data for the map?
questions.answer: The complete list of drinking fountains comes from [Berliner Wasserbetriebe (BWB)](https://www.bwb.de/de/trinkbrunnen.php), other refill spots from [Refill Germany](https://refill-deutschland.de/), the list of Volkshochschulen (VHS) from the [official City of Berlin website](https://www.berlin.de/vhs/volkshochschulen/), and the list of libraries is from the [Verbund der Öffentlichen Bibliotheken Berlins website](https://www.voebb.de/aDISWeb/app?service=direct/0/Home/$DirectLink&sp=SPROD00&sp=SWI01000154&noRedir).

newsPage.title: Latest News
newsPage.intro: Stay updated with the latest developments in our initiative.

news.title: Project Start
news.content: The initiative was officially kickstarted as the part of the citizen activation program of the Club Dialog e.V.

news.title: Engagement with Berliner Wasserbetriebe
news.content: Our suggestion for a fountain location in Pankow has been accepted for consideration and is now on the list for future possible locations. BWB drinking fountations map integration.

news.title: Engagement with Refill
news.content: Exchanged experience and insights about the water sources mapping. Refill spots map integration.

news.title: Engagement with the Pankow District Council
news.content: The Left Faction agreed to submit a citizen petition to the Pankow District Council for future discussion.

news.title: Water Map Beta Launch
news.content: We released a beta version of our map showing all known public water points in Berlin, and shared it for feedback with other organizations.

news.title: Website Launch
news.content: We launched a website where you can find information about our project and share your thoughts.

news.title: Info Campaign Launch
news.content: We're excited to announce the launch of our info campaign! Our goal is to share more about our initiative with the public across different districts. To support this, we've also created a new map in English—especially for this campaign.

news.title: The map is now in Russian!
news.content: Russian speakers in Berlin can now use our water map in their language to find the nearest drinking fountains and refill points, and even save the map to Google Maps in Russian.
